Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Experiment and Theory of the Electronic Structure of Correlated Electron Materials
Award.AbstractNarration: This workshop will bring together researchers to spur future developments of experimental and theoretical investigations of the electronic structure of correlated f-electron systems. In recent years, there has been rapid development of experimental techniques that provide direct measurements of both equilibrium and non-equilibrium electronic structures, as have new calculational methods for the time-independent and time-dependent electronic structures. The workshop will allow researchers at the forefront of their fields to discuss, exchange ideas and explore applications of novel spectroscopies to correlated f-electron systems in a focused forum and also bridge the ever widening gap between time-resolved experiments and non-equilibrium theory. The participants will include graduate students, junior and senior faculty at US universities and national laboratories, as well as international leaders in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workshop was held at Temple University for two and a half days, during the period of August 15th -17th 2016. The workshop was motivated by the rapid development of new spectroscopic tools which may prove valuable in the study of strongly correlated electronic materials.

Electronic materials are an indispensable ingredient of many modern electronic technologies. However, the presence of interactions between the electrons makes the properties of devices difficult to predict from first principles. This difficulty in predictive power hampers the development of new electronic technology and devices, crucial to our commercial and economic interests. The difficulty of limited predictive power is most acute for  f electron materials, such as  lanthanide and actinide compounds, where the electrons in the f orbitals are in close proximity to each other and therefore interact with each other strongly, Therefore, the study of the correlations exhibited by f electron materials is at the very frontiers of physics. New spectroscopic techniques have been developed that may shed insight onto the nature of the electron correlations. A goal of the workshop is to stimulate further developments that may allow the application of these new techniques to strongly correlated f electron systems. Since the new spectroscopic techniques often result in non-equilibrium states, theoretical techniques need to be developed that extend from equilibrium states to non-equilibrium states. The understanding of electronic correlations (non-linear interactions) and non-equilibrium dynamics has been set as a high national priority.

The interdisciplinary nature of the task required assembling a diverse array of researchers with a diverse array of research interests. The workshop brought together 40 scientists, from widely distributed geographical regions, interested in a wide range of novel spectroscopies and the electronic structure of correlated f electron materials.

Twentynine 20-30 minute presentations were made, which were followed by lengthy and lively discussions.  Many discussions took place in the coffee breaks, working lunches and some collaborations were proposed. The speakers, titles and abstracts of the talks, and videos of the talks are to be found at the conference website:

http://felectron.weebly.com/new-videos-of-talks.html

The current status of the field was examined, and various opportunities for further development of spectroscopic tools and accompanying advances in theoretical capabilities were identified.
